I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Subprogram 1 of the Second Private Sector and Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises 
Development  Program  (PSME2)  was  approved  by  the  Board  of  Directors  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) in October 2011.1 Regulatory impact assessment (RIA) forms an 
integral  part  of  PSME2,  and  the  Government  of  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic          
(Lao PDR) accordingly asked ADB for assistance in developing the government’s capacity to 
implement RIA, which will be the basis of subprogram 2 of PSME2, scheduled to be presented 
to the Board in 2013. In June 2012, a fact-finding mission visited the Lao PDR and reached an 
understanding with the government on the objectives, scope, implementation arrangements, 
cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference of the proposed technical assistance (TA) 
for Implementing Regulatory Impact Assessment. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.2   
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The government’s Seventh National Socio-Economic Development Plan targets gross 
domestic product (GDP) growth of at least 8% annually, with GDP per capita reaching at least 
$1,700  by  2015.3 In  seeking  to  achieve  these  targets,  the  government  recognizes  that 
development of the private sector and small and medium-sized enterprise (SMEs) 4 is critical for 
broad-based economic growth, especially if over-reliance on the natural resource sector is to be 
avoided. This is reflected in the government’s SME National Development Plan of 2012–2016. 
ADB supports the government’s priorities by focusing on expansion of the formal private sector 
through a supportive enabling environment.5 One of the most effective ways to do this is by 
introducing tools and systems that promote regulatory efficiency. 
 
3.  The work on regulatory impact assessment is based on the analytical work undertaken 
by ADB in 2009,6 which underlined three important conclusions. First, the study estimated that 
firms on average incur $483 annually to comply with the three most common licenses.7 Second, 
it costs the overall business community $32 million to comply with the three licenses.8 If all 
reported  enterprises  attained  the  three  permissions  then  the  total  cost  would  exceed          
KN500 billion (1.4% of GDP). Enterprises may also require additional sector-specific licenses 
that would raise total business compliance costs. A realistic estimate of business compliance 
costs was 1.5%–3.0% of GDP in 2008. Third, the burden of business regulatory costs falls 
heaviest on micro- and small enterprises. For example, the corresponding cost per employee

4.  These numbers resulted in strong government ownership of the RIA program. RIA is a 
systematic process for improving regulation and policy development, based on the three key 
principles  of  good  practice  regulation:  (i)  promoting  evidence-based  policy  development,            
(ii) transparency in policy making, and (iii) consultation with a wide range of stakeholders. RIA 
also documents the policy development process through the publication of a regulatory impact 
assessment checklist or regulatory impact statement, which reports on the consultation process 
and  tries  to  quantify  the  benefits  and  costs  of  the  proposed  regulation  on  the  business 
community, consumers and economy. Best international practice suggests that institutionalizing 
RIA in government requires three key elements: (i) multiple ministries and line agencies to carry 
out  and  demonstrate  the  value  of  RIA  throughout  the  government;  (ii)  a  legal  framework 
mandating  RIA  requirements  in  government;  (iii)  an  office  of  best  practice  regulation  that 
provides information advocacy on best practice, builds government capacity to carry out RIA, 
and monitors RIA compliance.  
 
5.  With  ADB  support  through  the  first  Private  Sector  and  Small  and  Medium-sized 
Enterprises Development Program 19 and PSME2, the RIA program in the Lao PDR follows 
good international practice, through sequencing a series of steps towards institutionalizing RIA 
in the national government. First, a RIA interagency taskforce, chaired by the vice minister for 
industry and commerce, was established in 2009 to oversee the drafting of a national strategy 
and build awareness of RIA in the national government.  The task force members include 
several ministries—the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI), 
and Ministry of Finance (MOF)—as well as the Prime Minister’s Office and the chamber of 
commerce.  The  first  RIA  program  pilot  was  implemented  in  the  Ministry  of  Industry  and 
Commerce  (MOIC)  in  2011.  The  MOIC  pilot  established  a  RIA  unit  under  the  permanent 
secretary’s office comprised of four MOIC staff. A manual, checklist and template for RIAs have 
been produced and endorsed. A RIA work plan listing the regulations and legislation that will be 
subject  to  a  RIA  was  endorsed  and  is  currently  being  implemented;  the  first  RIA  on  the 
Promotion of Small and Medium Enterprises Law, was completed and promulgated by the 
President on 16 January 2012. Second, the law on lawmaking included several provisions on 
RIA that will mandate RIA in national government after a transition period. Third, the draft RIA 
strategy includes references to the possibility of establishing an office of best practice regulation 
in the medium term. The adoption of the national strategy and the rollout of RIA units in other 
ministries are policy triggers for the second subprogram of PSME2.  
 
6.  The government has proposed setting up additional RIA units in MPI, MOF, and MOJ.            
In addition, the Economic Planning and Finance Committee of the National Assembly has also 
agreed to host a RIA unit. The committee views itself as a gatekeeper for ensuring the quality of 
proposed legislation and considers RIA as an important process and tool in that process. All 
agencies are preparing draft work plans to implement the RIA in 2012. Under ADB’s assistance 
(through  the  Urban  Development  and  Water  Division)  to  the  water  resources  sector,  a 
regulatory  expert  will  be  engaged  to  assist  with  RIA  in  that  sector.  This  activity  is  being 
coordinated between the Urban Development and Water Division and the Public Management, 
Financial Sector and Trade Division.

7.  Some lessons from the current RIA pilot at MOIC are applicable to expansion of the RIA.  
The challenges are (i) to build a critical mass of staff familiar with RIA processes; (ii) to ensure 
compliance with RIA within each agency (each line ministry has several departments and 
directorates that often act independent of each other, so effort is required to ensure their 
compliance);  and  (iii)  to  strengthen  the  interface  between  government  and  the  business 
community, including access to information from business generally, and SMEs in particular.    
 
8.  Therefore, the TA has three purposes: (i) assist the government in implementing RIA in 
four additional government units, and building a critical mass of staff with knowledge of the RIA 
tools; (ii) assist the government with an eventual national rollout of RIA, including establishment 
of an office of best practice regulation; and (iii) build demand for quality regulations through 
outreach activities with the business community and the public. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  The TA is necessary to expand the scope of the RIA program to MOJ, MOF, MPI, and 
the National Assembly and to build public demand for quality regulations. Demand for quality 
regulations will be increased through a series of public outreach activities, including developing 
a community of RIA practitioners outside the government, and updating estimates of the annual 
cost to business of compliance with general permissions. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA is RIA institutionalized in government. The indicator for the impact 
is a 15% reduction in the cost of business compliance. The outcome of the TA is RIA piloted 
across government, with an indicator of at least five preliminary RIAs completed in each RIA 
unit.10 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The three outputs are mutually reinforcing. First, the national RIA strategy, which will 
serve as an anchor document, will need to be endorsed by the government. The existing 
strategy was endorsed by the vice minister of MOIC, and although sufficient to set up the pilot 
unit in MOIC, a national rollout of the RIA will require that the strategy be updated to take into 
account the needs of the different ministries, and be approved by a higher level of government. 
The strategy will be circulated for comments and revisions will be made. The second output is to 
develop  and  strengthen  staff  capacity  in  the  RIA  units  of  the  participating  ministries  and 
committee  of  the  National  Assembly.  This  will  be  done  through  various  capacity-building 
initiatives, including focused workshops, attachment programs from line departments, and a 
study visit to a jurisdiction with developed RIA systems. Finally, the TA will support several 
public outreach programs to demonstrate the benefit of RIA to society, including the private 
sector. Support from the private sector is crucial to maintain the momentum of the RIA. This 
includes  a  proposed  international  conference  with  participation  from  Cambodia  and  the 
Philippines. ADB is supporting implementation of RIA in these countries and the sharing of 
experience will be useful.11 The full list of activities is contained in the design and monitoring

framework.  Achieving  the  full  impact  of  the  TA  will  require  effective  coordination  between 
ministries and between departments within a ministry in adopting a strategy and work plan; a 
risk to the project is that inadequate cost–benefit analysis capacity will reduce the impact of RIA, 
which may reduce the enthusiasm of line ministries to take on RIA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV), given the importance of this TA 
to support RIA as a component of subprogram 2 of PSME2.  The government will provide   
counterpart support in the form of office space for consultants, and other in-kind contributions.       
The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The executing agency will be MOIC. As the first ministry to pilot RIA, MOIC is the RIA 
champion  in  the  Lao  PDR.  The  implementing  agencies  will  be  MOJ,  MOF,  MPI,  and  the 
National Assembly. The government’s inter-ministerial steering committee—headed by the vice 
minister of MOIC and including representatives from MPI, MOF, MOJ, the National Assembly, 
and the private sector (Lao Chamber of Commerce)—will coordinate implementation of the TA. 
The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from November 2012 to November 2014. It will 
require 31 person-months of international consulting services and 12 person-months of national 
consulting  services,  including  a  strategic  policy  expert  (international,  7  person-months);              
2 regulatory experts (international, 12 person-months each); and one communications and 
media expert (national, 12 person-months). All consultants will be engaged on an individual 
basis.  
 
14.  All consultants will be hired according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Equipment and office supplies to be financed by the TA 
will be procured by the consultants or ADB in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance 
with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). All equipment procured under this TA will be turned over to the executing agency upon 
completion of the TA. The outputs and outcome evaluation will be disseminated through the 
international conference and RIA reports published by the Government. The terms of reference 
for consultants are in Appendix 3.     
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the Lao People's Democratic Republic for Implementing Regulatory Impact  
Assessment, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  International strategic policy expert (international, 7 person-months). The strategic 
policy expert will  assist the Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic provide 
overall guidance to the regulatory impact assessment (RIA) interagency taskforce on strategic 
policy development and implementation of the national RIA strategy. The consultant will also 
provide guidance to the two international regulatory experts. The consultant should have an 
economics  or finance  degree,  with  at  least  5 years  of  professional  experience  working  in 
economic policy analysis and RIAs. Early career experience with an office of regulatory best 
practice or the equivalent is necessary.  
2.  The consultant will assist (i) the Ministry of Industry and Commerce to serve as the RIA 
champion for the Lao People’s Democratic Republic; and (ii) the Economic Secretariat of the 
National  Assembly  regarding  policy  development,  implementation  of  the  RIA  strategy,  and 
establishment of an office  to oversee the RIA pilot in government.  
3.  Detailed tasks are to: 
(i)  assist the RIA interagency taskforce in finalizing the RIA strategy, with the aim of 
having it endorsed through a decree of the Prime Minister;  
(ii)  provide support to the government in institutionalizing RIA through the draft Law 
on Lawmaking; 
(iii)  work with the RIA taskforce and Prime Minister’s Office to develop a roadmap for 
establishing  an  Office  of  RIA  to  oversee  implementation  of  the  RIA  across 
government; 
(iv)  provide  strategic  policy  assistance  to  government  on  implementing  the  RIA, 
including  assistance  to  finalize  the  RIA  manual,  guidelines,  templates  and 
business process; 
(v)  provide guidance to the two international regulatory experts on training staff at 
the  line  ministries  and  in  carrying  out  RIA  assignments  at  the  respective 
ministries; 
(vi)   support the RIA taskforce to produce a first annual report on regulation; 
(vii)  coordinate the work of the RIA team across ministries to ensure consistency and 
the quality of all reports produced by the other RIA experts; and 
(viii)  design the content of the RIA e-learning module for policy makers and supervise 
information technology graphic design and programming of the e-module. 
 
4.  The main deliverables will be: (i) a finalized national RIA strategy ready for endorsement 
by the Prime Minister’s Office; (ii) a finalized and endorsed RIA manual, guidelines, templates 
and business processes; and (iii) an annual report on regulation.  
 
5.  International  regulatory  expert  (international,  12  person-months).  The  regulatory 
expert will assist the government to expand regulatory review systems. The consultant should 
have an economics or finance degree, and at least 3 years professional experience working in 
economic policy analysis and RIAs. Early career experience with an office of regulatory best 
practice or the equivalent and some experience in RIA capacity building is necessary.

6.  The scope of this consultancy will be to assist the RIA line agencies (Ministry of Industry 
and Commerce, Ministry of Justice, and Ministry of Planning and Investment) in RIA training and 
carrying out RIA work plans.  
7.  Detailed tasks are to: 
(i)   assist the focal persons to develop an annual RIA work plan for carrying out RIA 
on a selection of existing or proposed regulations and legislation for 2013–2015;  
(ii)   implement staff training for each agency and RIA tools (e.g., initial RIA, full RIA, 
and standard cost model); and  
(iii)   assist staff of each agency to complete five RIAs by the end of the assignment. 
 
8.  The main deliverables will be: (i) develop and have endorsed each agency’s work plan 
for the next 3 years, (ii) carry out staff training, and (iii) complete five RIAs for each agency.    
 
9.  Regulatory expert (international, 12 person-months). The regulatory expert will assist 
the  government  to  expand  regulatory  review  systems  in  the  national  government.  The 
consultant should have an economics or finance degree. They should have at least 3 years 
professional experience working in economic policy analysis and RIAs. Early career experience 
with an office of regulatory best practice or equivalent and some experience in RIA capacity 
building is necessary.  
10.  The consultant will assist the MOF and National Assembly in RIA training and carrying 
out RIA work plans.  
 
11.  Detailed tasks are to: 
(i)   assist the focal persons to develop an annual RIA work plan for carrying out RIA 
on a selection of existing or proposed regulations, and legislation for the next 3 
years;  
(ii)   implement staff training for each agency and RIA tools (e.g., initial RIA, full RIA, 
standard cost model); and 
(iii)   assist staff of each agency to complete one RIA by the end of the assignment. 
 
12.  The main deliverables will be: (i) develop and have endorsed each agency’s work plan 
for the next 3 years, (ii) carry out staff training, and (iii) one completed RIA for each agency.  
 
13.  Communications  and  media  expert  (national,  12  person  months).  The 
communications  expert  will  assist  the  government  develop  and  implement  a  mass 
communications  and media  action  plan.  The consultant  should  have a  communications  or 
related degree, and at least 3 years professional experience working in media. 
   
14.  They  will  assist  the  RIA  taskforce  and  each  ministry  to  develop  and  carry  out  a 
communications and media strategy to promote RIA awareness within government, the national 
assembly, and the public.  
 
15.  Detailed tasks are to: 
 
(i)   assist the RIA taskforce develop a mass communications and media strategy 
and action plan, including identifying the target market and effective media to 
promote advocacy and dissemination of RIA to the community;  
(ii)   assist the RIA taskforce draft press releases and assist with preparation of other 
materials for dissemination;

Appendix 3  11 
 
(iii)   liaise with the RIA taskforce and media to arrange public outreach activities; and 
(iv)   undertake other media activities as requested. 
 
16.  The main deliverables will be: (i) develop and have endorsed by the RIA taskforce a 
mass  communication  and  media  strategy  and  action  plan;  (ii)  prepare  materials  for 
dissemination through the media, including a series of press releases in 2012 and 2013; and           
(iii) organize at least four media conferences on RIA.
